data.text: Feet Balls Burning when Cycling

I need different shoes. I have the pearl izumi mtn bike right now and I love the fit, how durable they are and overall they are amazing. Except I have a ton of issues with the balls of my feet burning, sometimes to the point that I'm in tears. I do a lot of long distance riding and bike packing and I need something to help with the insane pain. I've tried expensive inserts, different socks, etc. And nothing helps. Anyone have any issues like this and what do you use? I was looking at more of a lace up sneaker style but I'm not sure. I have a 640 mile race in September and I need to figure it out. Picture of my shoes after my last race for fun 💜🚲

Midsole Cleats https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=t7oGuel--Lc
Ride with More Speed & Comfort (with a Midfoot Cleat Position?)
youtube.com
data.author: Christian Eckert

data.text:
I had the same problem. Change your pedals, not your shoes. https://www.bikeparts.co.uk/products/shimano-pd-m8120-deore-xt-trail-wide-spd-pedal?currency=GBP&variant=39977308749981&utm_medium=cpc&utm_source=google&utm_campaign=Google%20Shopping&gclid=CjwKCAjwt7SWBhAnEiwAx8ZLanoFOpuTIP5ZUsGXmYuOChJovZCuNl1pd1lFpbYlGhu73dG_2om4ZxoCD5cQAvD_BwE
Shimano PD-M8120 Deore XT trail wide SPD pedal
bikeparts.co.uk
data.author: Steve Coombs

data.text: Do a bike fit. And perhaps stop using cleats.
data.author: Johan Gahm

data.text: I have and I race so I prefer cleats
data.author: Tatianna Wawrzynski

data.text: I also prefer cleats but apparently they aren’t that important from a physio economic standpoint if that makes sense. Your pain seems real.
data.author: Johan Gahm

data.text: me thinks this syndrome is called hot-feet. Lots of info out there on it. Good luck to you!
data.author: Johan Gahm

data.text: Same problem. The only solution I found till now is to use Shimano spd sandals. Not really fashionables but no more pain! I ride in Elsass I can use them from mai to October with or without socks. I know that some people use them with merino socks for colder weather.
data.author: Gé Bé Caredio

data.text: interesting. I will have to look at them. How are they in really crazy terrain where you have to hike a bike?
data.author: Tatianna Wawrzynski

data.text: oh no problems with mud or gravel . And after you can just go inside the shower with them at your feet!
data.author: Gé Bé Caredio

data.text: Open toe...too dangerous in my opinion.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: that was my opinion too. But after a thinking I arrived at conclusion that if you fall you lose your skin everywhere else ( hands knees elbows even face) so in the end open toes or not is not so different. And they are long enough to not scratch your feet while stopping of course.
data.author: Gé Bé Caredio
Gé Bé Caredio

data.text: A couple of years ago, someone in one of the bike touring groups showed pics of his mangled feet whilst in a San Francisco hospital. Wore open sandals. After seeing those pics, I switched entirely to closed shoes. Then, earlier this year, my ortho surgeon told me the story of a patient of his that wore sandals (flip flops I think) and she had an accident on a shared use path (families walking, joggers, slow biking, etc.) and she had a toe ripped off. To put it back entails months of bedrest. So, it's not a matter of losing some skin which is no big deal. Toes and feet are incredibly important to mobility and quality of life. You lose a big toe and you will never walk properly again. Go ask a podiatrist. If you insist on sandals, get the closed toe one from Bike Nashbar.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: What pedal/cleats are you on ? I used to used spd and always had burning soles and/or numb toes. Much better since switching to look style pedals and rigid sole shoes. Agreed, mire difficult to walk in but on 200+ rides I'm cycling more than I'm walking!
data.author: Stewart Paterson

data.text: I am using spd crank brothers. My only concern with that is that I do a LOT of hike a bike. My last long bike packing race I hiked over 100 miles 😳🤪
data.author: Tatianna Wawrzynski

data.text: ah yes. Quite specific needs
data.author: Stewart Paterson

data.text:
For the past 50 years of daily riding most of my bicycling has been barefoot. Even on my longest rides i never have comfort issues…. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=bo1OXYqGwRI&list=PLAdOBRoqBbpssXBqKlxOfzAwSYRoVrVTS&fbclid=IwAR11jEAC2kSgzgNp66vpDCWVC7erb1xYOkvAQH-FIV0qFzWK9Q16VawYC64

data.text: Or at least try to shift them to the back
data.author: Christian Eckert

data.text: I'm definitely going to try this
data.author: Tatianna Wawrzynski

data.text: if the cleat goes towards the heel 1cm, the saddle has to go down also, maybe around 0.3cm, just try.
data.author: Christian Eckert

data.text: Wanted to second this - my bike fitter moved my spd mountain cleats back just a bit and it made a difference for me (he adjusted the saddle at the same time). Good luck !
data.author: Doyle Ravnaas

data.text: Tatianna Wawrzynski You could try Keen sandals. They have some with an SPD cleat. Hard to get in some countries but if you can find them they are well worth having.
data.author: Marilyn Brisby

data.text: I have not read through the replies but is it something that a change of cleat position might help with? Just an idea
data.author: James Elias

data.text:
Here is an excellent comment from British Cycling. https://www.britishcycling.org.uk/knowledge/training/health-recovery/article/izn20141104-Physiotherapy-Foot-Pain-on-the-Bike-0#:~:text=Hot%2Dfoot,foot%27s%20five%20long%20metatarsal%20bones.
Foot pain on the bike
britishcycling.org.uk
data.author: Patrick Millar

data.text: Try getting shoes with heat moldable insoles. They would conform to your feet. I know specialized makes them. I have high arches. I have specialized body geometry insoles with higher arches (I didn’t bother with the moldable, because these work well for me. I’ve always used specialized shoes because I know they fit me well. You have to find shoes that work well for you. When I used to race XC many people loved Sidi shoes. I was always too cheap. But my mid level specialized Comp MTB shoes got me through multiple 24 hour races back in the day, because they fit me properly.
data.author: Tobie Baldwin

data.text: I switched to flats because of hotfoot. Allows more movement on the pedal.
data.author: Adam Abbas

data.text: Morton’s neuroma? Is this the cause? If so, custom footbeds and then the nerve removed was the solution.
data.author: Emma Atkinson

data.text: Ask jack ultracyclist he broke the world record last year 3.500 klm in 7 days he just completed his 26 th everest this week climbing 520000 metres so far i think he will give you good imfo he my nephew good luck
data.author: Mike Thompson

data.text: Lake MX237 or 238 has extra toe room and cleats allow moving back a long way. Excellent shoe.
data.author: Richard Gate

data.text: Tried a professional bike fit?
data.author: Derrick Murray

data.text: I have 😊
data.author: Tatianna Wawrzynski

data.text: I had the same problem and now have two different solutions : on my road bike I have switched to look style pedals ; on my tourer I have moved the SPD cleat back as far as it will go and also switched to pedals that are SPD on one side and flat on the other ( so if the “hot foot” starts I switch to the flat side to let the foot calm down and then switch back again when it has stopped hurting ). It works for me.
data.author: Steve Carden

data.text: I just got new crank brothers pedals that are spd on one side and flat on the other, I am hoping that helps me too 🤞
data.author: Tatianna Wawrzynski

data.text: I have never had a problem with sidi shoes. Comfortable out of the box, durable. Not sure how hike a bike would be in these shoes though.
data.author: Nicole Dewey

data.text:
I think I have the same problem. Look up splay foot, maybe it applies to you. It requires specific (not expensive) insoles. When cycling for a long time, you are putting a lot of pressure on the forefoot, causing the pain. https://www.physio-pedia.com/Splay_Foot Hope this helps.
Splay Foot
physio-pedia.com
data.author: Bart Van der Perre

data.text: I have a similar problem, and was told my shoes had composite soles and therefore flexed too much causing pressure. An alternative is a stiffer composite shoe or a carbon sole, I’m trying the first option and will get a mouldable insole. Fingers crossed.
data.author: Ken Neth

data.text: I have the same problem, I believe I have neuropathy in my feet, which really kicks in after about 3 hours of riding. I am going to try moving my cleats back as suggested below. I have tried using a topical lotion that contains menthol, hemp oils and some other things that does give a bit of relief, but has not proven to be 100% effective, so I’m hoping the cleat adjustment will make the difference!
data.author: Jack Kukowski

data.text: Have a pro fit your cleats. Even a couple of millimeters can make big difference.
data.author: Bill Heimann

data.text: Flat pedals, comfortable shoes for long distance touring is my suggestion. I think clips limit your foot position too much. Racing is another story.
data.author: Brenna Sullivan

data.text: I had similar problems and switched to carbon shoe sole and also changed inner sole to moldable soles.
data.author: Rainer Weissenberger

data.text: Pull up as you pedal to counter the pushing down. Also adjust the tension of the shoe as your feet swell during your ride.
data.author: Edward Gregory

data.text: I need a stiff bottom and wide toe. They stopped making Bontragers ? I loved them. Looks like what you are showing... Hot foot -- putting a folded new maxi pad there will help, but I just went to Flat pedals and no more burning at all.
data.author: Jenny Sun

data.text: Once I started riding centuries and planning long tours, clipless started hurting my feet. So I started putting wide downhill flats on my bicycles and I only wear Chaco sandals anyway. So I can hike my bike if I have to, and cleaning my footwear means I put my feet under a hose.
data.author: Eric Knudstrup

data.text: Recommend using Specialized insoles and metatarsal separators. Also helpful to visit a good bike fitter who can very quickly check for varus / vagus issues. Another option is Solestar insole - but they are intended for different fit than most recreational cyclist - though in the correct scenario are amazing.
data.author: Tim Smith

data.text: What you are experiencing is generally grouped into metatarsalgia and can include issues from many sources in the foot bed. But generally following symptomatic relief is a good starting point.
data.author: Tim Smith

data.text: Stiffer sole, wider pedal platform or both. Good Luck, Enjoy 🚴🏼‍♀️💪😀
data.author: James Prescott

data.text: I put some superfeet insoles in mine. Their insoles are crap.
data.author: Bruce Nikolai

data.text: I had this problem years ago when we first started increasing our miles ready for a tour. I discovered a hard inflexible sole to the shoe was the best. Like running shoes, go for a half size bigger to allow for foot swelling. I went for mtb muddy fox, with velcro fastening. We are all different though. Hope this helps x.
data.author: Kathy O'Keefe
